Name: Bronze figure of three cats seated in a row
Description: A small bronze votive offering depicting three cats seated in a row, with a loop for suspension on the back of each. The cat was sacred to Bastet, originally the goddess of ointment. It became a prominent animal in Egyptian religion after the rise of the 22nd Dynasty, a family of kings from Bubastis, city of Bast. This triple figure was found at Memphis, where there was a temple to Bast. In the nearby desert cliffs at Saqqara catacombs contained hundreds of thousands of cat mummies deposited between the Late Period and Roman Period (7th C BC to 1st C AD).
